title: Is Dr. Oz Anti-Gun? Senatorial Candidate and Reality TV Doc Denies ...
summary: Dr. Mehmet Oz, a Pennsylvania senatorial candidate and former reality TV doctor, faces criticism from gun-rights advocates over articles published under his name advocating for gun control measures. These articles, from 2017 and 2019, supported policies such as an assault weapon ban, red flag laws, universal gun purchaser licensing, and mandatory waiting periods. Oz denies writing these articles, attributing them mainly to his co-author, Dr. Michael Roizen, who confirmed that Oz's involvement was minimal. Critics, including Republican operative Arthur Schwartz and Oz's GOP primary opponent Dave McCormick, express skepticism, suggesting Oz is now disowning the articles after deciding to run for Senate. McCormick accused Oz of having a history of opposing the Second Amendment. Despite Oz's claims, gun-rights groups and individuals distrust his stance, viewing the articles as reflective of his beliefs. The Pennsylvania primary election is scheduled for May 17th.

title: Dr. Oz denies writing gun control advocacy columns, business partner ...
summary: Dr. Mehmet Oz, a Republican senatorial candidate from Pennsylvania, has disavowed a series of columns bearing his byline that advocated for gun control, explaining that his role in these writings was minimal. His business partner, Dr. Michael Roizen, has claimed full responsibility, stating that he took over the management of the 'YouDocs' syndicated column due to Oz's other commitments. From 2017 to 2019, these columns supported various gun control measures such as assault weapon bans and red flag laws. Oz's campaign counters this narrative by emphasizing his long-standing support for the Second Amendment and his record as a gun owner. Despite criticism from political opponents like Dave McCormick, Oz maintains his pro-gun stance, targeting attempts to link him with anti-gun rhetoric and accusing McCormick of ties to pro-gun control advocates.

title: Do you agree with Mehmet Oz that said Americans should have less access ...
summary: Mehmet Oz's suggestion that Americans should have less access to guns and adopt a gun ban similar to New Zealand's was met with strong opposition from several commentators. Critics argue that America's unique cultural and historical context makes such policies inappropriate, with some emphasizing the constitutional right to bear arms. They contend that disarming law-abiding citizens would not deter criminals who already possess firearms illegally. Additionally, some point to New Zealand's experience, where gun violence reportedly rose despite a clampdown on firearms, suggesting that the ban has not been effective in reducing gun crime. Oz's credibility was also questioned, with references to his previous controversial actions, such as promoting unproven medical treatments. Ultimately, many argue that the U.S. should not follow other countries' models without considering its distinct challenges and rights.

title: Mehmet Ozs policy on Gun Control - isidewith.com
summary: Mehmet Oz, a Republican candidate in the 2022 US Senate race in Pennsylvania, opposes implementing more restrictions on gun purchases. Republican Party voters who support Oz also prioritize this stance as a significant issue. The party advocates for passing a national 'stand your ground' law, emphasizing the right to self-defense for law-abiding citizens. However, it is noted that Oz has not yet publicly responded directly to inquiries about his stance on this issue, and there is ongoing research into his voting and donor records.

title: Gun law in New Zealand - Wikipedia
summary:
The gun laws in New Zealand are governed by the Arms Act 1983, with several amendments following major incidents like the Aramoana massacre and the Christchurch mosque shootings. New Zealand's gun laws focus on vetting firearm owners rather than registering firearms themselves. There are around 300,000 licensed firearm owners and 1.5 million firearms in the country. Applicants for gun licenses must be vetted by police, have no criminal or psychiatric issues, and meet storage requirements. A 'Category A' license is most common, allowing for ownership of sporting rifles and shotguns.

Significant changes occurred after the Christchurch mosque shootings in 2019, when legislation was passed to ban semi-automatic firearms and high-capacity magazines. The government introduced an amnesty and buyback scheme for prohibited weapons. New Zealand does not allow firearms for self-defense, and personal protection for VIPs is handled by the police or defense forces. Over time, there have been calls for stricter gun control, including a national firearms register and tighter licensing, supported by groups like the New Zealand Police Association and lobbied by entities like Gun Control NZ.

Additional endorsements are required for owning pistols, military-style semi-automatic firearms, and restricted weapons, with restrictions on ammunition. The government initiated new legislative reforms after the Christchurch mosque incidents, leading to debates over gun registry data and overseas visitor restrictions. By mid-2019, more than 19,100 firearms had been surrendered during the buyback scheme. Major political parties in New Zealand generally support bipartisan approaches to gun control, with the exception of the ACT Party, which opposed the ban on semi-automatics.

About 250,000 people hold a New Zealand firearms licence. title: Ads Attacking Dr. Oz - FactCheck.org
summary: A super PAC supporting Dave McCormick, a Republican Senate candidate in Pennsylvania, has launched ads against his opponent Dr. Mehmet Oz, portraying him as a 'Hollywood liberal' and 'RINO.' The ads accuse Oz of hiring illegal immigrants, supporting abortion rights, and advocating for gun control, referencing red flag laws discussed on his TV show. They also criticize his stance on Black Lives Matter, highlighting a social media post about systemic racism in healthcare. However, Oz has stated he does not support the Black Lives Matter organization's actions. Ozâ€™s campaign has clarified he is a passive shareholder in the company accused of hiring illegal immigrants and has no involvement in its practices. He describes himself as '100% Pro-Life' but with certain exceptions, and as a proud gun owner opposed to any restrictions on Second Amendment rights. Oz has promoted aspects of the Affordable Care Act, encouraging public engagement with the law for better healthcare access. Despite the attacks, Oz leads in the Republican primary, with McCormick close behind.
snippet: The ads also point to prior statements Oz has made on the Affordable Care Act, abortion and gun laws. Oz has taken public positions in the campaign contrary to those past statements.
